title: 'I thought this is it' Martine McCutcheon thanks cabbie for saving her from terrifying sexual assault ordeal

text:
'I thought this is it' Martine McCutcheon thanks cabbie for saving her from terrifying sexual assault ordeal The former EastEnders star opened up on her horrific attack on Loose Women   Share   Comments By Hayley Minn 14:13, 22 FEB 2017 TV Video Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Watch Next Martine McCutcheon reveals details of Love Actual Watch this video again Watch Next Loose Women: Linda Robson gets a DILDO out after 0:27 Loose Women: Martine McCutcheon opens up on suffe 0:49 Joel Dommett tells Martine McCutcheon to stop fli 0:31 Katy Perry superfan insults her hair WHEN LIE DET 0:40 Ben Price reveals why he's leaving Coronation Str 0:39 Video will play in  Martine McCutcheon thanks cabbie who saved her from attacker Share this video Watch Next   Share   Comments Get soaps   Martine McCutcheon has revealed the terrifying moment she was grabbed by a car of men and dragged along the road, while they shouted “violent sexual comments” at her. 
The 40-year-old ex- EastEnders star was walking through South Kensington on her way to a friend’s birthday when a car pulled up near her, close to the Natural History Museum. 
Speaking on Loose Women, she said: “There was a gaggle of guys in there.
“They were saying what they wanted to do to me, and then another one would do it… violent sexual comments.
“As I went to say go away, one of them got hold of my coat collar.
“I was running with the car, it was still moving.
Read More Martine McCutcheon reveals Love Actually Comic Relief details ahead of Hugh Grant reunion Martine suffered a horrific ordeal (Photo: ITV/Loose Women) “I was worried if I stopped the wheels would go over my feet.
“I was panicking so much. I just thought ‘this is it’. I thought they’d drag me into the car and do what they wanted to do to me.”
A black cab eventually stopped in front of the car, and the driver immediately came round to help her.
She said: “He came round and said ‘you stay there’, then he said ‘what on Earth do you think you’re playing at?’
Read More Love Actually sequel for Comic Relief will NOT pay tribute to Alan Rickman - here's why She was saved by a cabbie (Photo: ITV/Loose Women) “He got me in the taxi and drove me to a petrol station where he got me a can of coke because I was shaking, and he took me to my party.
“I asked if I could pay and he said no, have a lovely time, and please get a car back and don’t walk.”
Adding she never got a chance to thank the driver, Martine said: “I just want to say wherever you are, thank you so much.”
*Loose Women continues on ITV1 weekdays at 12.30pm
